question: For purposes of applying the related provisions referenced in Article 12 of Chapter 4 of Own Funds (CRR) Part, how should an institution determine whether a recognised amount qualifies as “gain on sale” in the context of a securitisation transaction, including the required accounting and balance-sheet conditions?
gold_answer: When considering the related provisions referenced in Article 12 of Chapter 4 of Own Funds (CRR) Part [#SRC:8b849964a198cf45], an institution should treat “gain on sale” as a defined concept that hinges on both recognition and linkage to securitisation-related future income. Specifically, “gain on sale” means any recognised gain on sale for the institution that is recorded as an increase in any element of own funds, and that gain must be associated with future margin income arising from a sale of securitised assets. In addition, the definition requires that the securitised assets are removed from the institution’s balance sheet in the context of a securitisation transaction [#TGT:6cc8b722cd5cd1e7]. Accordingly, the institution’s determination is not based merely on a sale event; it must confirm (i) the gain is recognised, (ii) it increases an element of own funds, (iii) it is tied to future margin income from the sale of securitised assets, and (iv) the assets are removed from the balance sheet as part of the securitisation transaction. This aligns the definitional trigger with the cross-referenced related provisions.

question: When you see a note pointing to related provisions in Article 12 of Chapter 4 of Own Funds (CRR) Part, what does “gain on sale” mean for an institution in a securitisation transaction, and what facts must be true for it to count?
gold_answer: The note directing you to related provisions in Article 12 of Chapter 4 of Own Funds (CRR) Part [#SRC:8b849964a198cf45] should be read together with the definition of “gain on sale,” because the related provisions depend on using that term consistently. For an institution, “gain on sale” means a recognised gain on sale that is recorded as an increase in any element of own funds, and it must be associated with future margin income that arises from selling securitised assets. It also requires that those securitised assets are removed from the institution’s balance sheet, and that this removal happens in the context of a securitisation transaction [#TGT:6cc8b722cd5cd1e7]. So, to decide whether something is “gain on sale,” you need to confirm more than just that a sale occurred: the gain must be recognised, it must increase own funds, it must relate to future margin income from the sale, and the assets must be taken off the balance sheet as part of the securitisation transaction. These conditions together define when the term applies under the related provisions.

question: When determining its basic own funds, how must a firm apply the required deductions for participations so that the reduction of basic own funds for certain participations in financial and credit institutions is made in the correct tier corresponding to where the participation increased the related undertaking’s own funds, and only for the portion exceeding the stated aggregate threshold and excluding the specified category of participations?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the participations-related adjustments as mandatory deductions and ensure they are taken from the corresponding tier in which the participation increased the own funds of the related undertaking, rather than applying a generic or mismatched tier treatment [#SRC:c6721f79b60bc179]. In parallel, when the firm is determining its basic own funds, it must reduce basic own funds by the relevant part of the value of participations in financial and credit institutions (other than the excluded category of participations) only to the extent that the aggregate value of those participations exceeds the specified percentage threshold measured against the referenced items [#TGT:ddb71c7a316d2892]. Read together, this means the firm must (i) identify which participations fall within the target reduction requirement (including the exclusion), (ii) calculate the amount subject to reduction by applying the “exceeds threshold” limitation, and then (iii) execute that reduction as a deduction taken from the appropriate tier that corresponds to how the participation affected the related undertaking’s own funds. This aligns the basic own funds reduction mechanics with the tier-specific deduction obligation.

question: If a firm is working out its basic own funds and has participations in financial and credit institutions, what must it do to reduce basic own funds only for the amount above the threshold (and not for the excluded participations), and how must it make sure the deduction is taken from the same tier where the participation increased the related undertaking’s own funds?
gold_answer: The firm must do two linked things. First, it must apply the participations deduction requirement by making the deductions from the corresponding tier in which the participation increased the own funds of the related undertaking, so the deduction is aligned to the tier impact of the participation rather than being taken arbitrarily [#SRC:c6721f79b60bc179]. Second, for the specific purpose of determining its basic own funds, the firm must reduce its basic own funds by the relevant part of the value of participations in financial and credit institutions, but only to the extent the aggregate value of those participations exceeds the stated percentage threshold against the referenced items, and it must not include the participations that are expressly carved out from this reduction requirement [#TGT:ddb71c7a316d2892]. In practice, the firm should identify the in-scope participations, exclude the carved-out category, compute the aggregate value and the excess over the threshold, and then reduce basic own funds by that excess amount while ensuring the deduction is recorded in the tier that corresponds to where the participation increased the related undertaking’s own funds.

question: When an institution has stopped calculating exposure values for its derivative positions under the applicable approach and seeks to restart, what must it do to be permitted to resume that calculation, and how does that permission interact with the requirement to calculate a single exposure value at netting set level?
gold_answer: If an institution has ceased calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions under the applicable approach, it is not automatically allowed to restart that calculation. It is permitted to resume calculating the exposure value of its derivative positions only where it demonstrates to the competent authority that the relevant conditions have been met for an uninterrupted period of one year [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]. In parallel, institutions have an ongoing obligation to calculate a single exposure value at netting set level in accordance with the applicable framework, subject to the stated qualification in the target provision [#TGT:b16c73e93c0f2966]. Read together, the permission to resume a particular method for derivative-position exposure values is conditional on a one-year, uninterrupted compliance demonstration to the competent authority, while the institution must still ensure that its exposure measurement is produced as a single exposure value at netting set level as required. Accordingly, any restart of derivative exposure-value calculations must be aligned with, and not treated as a substitute for, the netting-set-level single exposure value obligation, and the institution should be prepared to evidence both the one-year conditions and the resulting netting-set exposure value outcome.

question: In circumstances where an institution has ceased calculating derivative-position exposure values and intends to restart, what conditions must be evidenced to the competent authority before the institution may resume, and what calculation outcome must the institution still deliver at netting set level?
gold_answer: An institution that has ceased calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions under the applicable approach may resume calculating those exposure values only if it can demonstrate to the competent authority that the relevant conditions have been satisfied continuously for an uninterrupted period of one year [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]. This is a gating permission: without that demonstration over the full one-year period, the institution is not permitted to restart the derivative-position exposure-value calculation under that approach. Separately, and regardless of the restart permission, institutions are required to calculate a single exposure value at netting set level in accordance with the applicable framework, subject to the stated qualification in the target provision [#TGT:b16c73e93c0f2966]. The combined effect is that the institution must (i) meet the precondition for being allowed to resume the derivative exposure-value calculation by evidencing uninterrupted satisfaction of the conditions to the competent authority, and (ii) ensure that its exposure measurement is expressed as a single exposure value at netting set level. The permission governs whether the institution may restart a specific calculation approach; the obligation governs the required netting-set-level output.

question: If an institution stopped calculating exposure values for its derivative positions and now wants to start again, what does it need to show to the competent authority to be allowed to restart, and what exposure value must it still calculate at netting set level?
gold_answer: When an institution has ceased calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions under the applicable approach, it can only restart that calculation if it demonstrates to the competent authority that the relevant conditions have been met continuously for an uninterrupted period of one year [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]. That permission to resume is conditional and depends on the institution’s evidence to the competent authority over the full one-year period. At the same time, institutions have a separate requirement to calculate a single exposure value at netting set level in accordance with the applicable framework, subject to the stated qualification in the target provision [#TGT:b16c73e93c0f2966]. Putting these together: restarting the derivative-position exposure-value calculation is allowed only after the one-year uninterrupted-conditions demonstration, but the institution must still produce the required single exposure value at netting set level. In practice, the institution should treat the restart permission as a prerequisite for using that approach again, while ensuring that its exposure measurement process continues to deliver the netting-set-level single exposure value outcome required by the target obligation.

question: After an institution has stopped calculating exposure values for derivative positions, when can it start calculating them again, and how does that fit with the rule that institutions must calculate one exposure value for each netting set?
gold_answer: An institution that has ceased calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions under the applicable approach is only permitted to resume calculating those exposure values if it can demonstrate to the competent authority that the relevant conditions have been met for an uninterrupted period of one year [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]. This means the institution needs a continuous one-year track record of meeting the conditions and must be able to evidence that to the competent authority before it can restart. Separately, institutions must calculate a single exposure value at netting set level in accordance with the applicable framework, subject to the stated qualification in the target provision [#TGT:b16c73e93c0f2966]. So even if the institution is working toward being allowed to restart the derivative-position exposure-value calculation, it still has to ensure that its exposure measurement is expressed as one exposure value at the netting set level. The permission controls when the institution may restart a particular way of calculating derivative exposure values; the obligation controls the required netting-set-level exposure value result that must be produced.

question: To comply with Insurance Company – Capital Resources Requirements, what must a firm do on an ongoing basis regarding the level of its capital resources relative to its CR Requirement?
gold_answer: To comply with Insurance Company – Capital Resources Requirements, a firm is required to ensure that its capital resources are continuously sufficient when measured against its CR Requirement. In practice, this means the firm must maintain capital resources at all times that are at least equal to, and may be higher than, the firm’s CR Requirement, so that the firm remains in compliance on an ongoing (not periodic) basis. The compliance obligation is framed by the requirement to “comply with Insurance Company – Capital Resources Requirements” [#SRC:4ea2648a6342b626] and is operationalized by the specific duty that the firm must maintain capital resources equal to or in excess of its CR Requirement at all times [#TGT:34d0efbb3e1b0536]. Accordingly, the firm should treat the CR Requirement as the minimum threshold for its capital resources and ensure that its capital position does not fall below that threshold at any time, since the obligation applies continuously rather than only at reporting dates. This links the general compliance expectation in the source to the concrete, measurable capital maintenance standard in the target.

question: If a firm needs to comply with Insurance Company – Capital Resources Requirements, what does it have to do at all times with its capital resources compared with its CR Requirement?
gold_answer: Complying with Insurance Company – Capital Resources Requirements means the firm has to keep its capital resources at a level that continuously meets the minimum standard set by its CR Requirement. The source establishes that the firm must comply with the Insurance Company – Capital Resources Requirements [#SRC:4ea2648a6342b626]. The target then states what that compliance looks like in practical terms: the firm must maintain capital resources at all times that are equal to or greater than its CR Requirement [#TGT:34d0efbb3e1b0536]. So the firm cannot allow its capital resources to drop below the CR Requirement at any point, because the obligation is “at all times,” not just at the end of a month, quarter, or reporting period. In effect, the CR Requirement functions as the firm’s floor for capital resources, and the firm must manage its capital position so it stays at or above that floor continuously to satisfy the compliance obligation described in the source and specified in the target.

question: When the PRA makes an overall assessment of whether a home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, what is the scope and purpose of that assessment in relation to the PRA’s authorisation and supervision functions, and how should this be distinguished from any advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury? In outlining the procedure, identify the key factors the PRA weighs, including cooperation and the firm-specific and group-level supervision considerations.
gold_answer: In making an overall assessment of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, the PRA evaluates whether the home regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives, considering the relevant factors in the round and placing considerable weight on the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. This assessment also takes into account supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, and it considers the nature and scale of the firm’s activities in the UK as part of the PRA’s procedural approach to reaching an overall view [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. The scope of this equivalence assessment is confined to outcomes achieved for the purposes of authorisation and supervision by the PRA, and it must be distinguished from any separate advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]. While the PRA may give such advice to HM Treasury, HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes, so the PRA’s overall assessment should not be treated as a substitute for, or determinative of, HM Treasury’s separate determinations [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581].

question: If the PRA is deciding overall whether a home state supervisor is equivalent, what does that decision apply to, and what does it not apply to (especially compared with HM Treasury decisions)? Also, what does the PRA look at in practice, like cooperation and how the firm and its group are supervised in the UK?
gold_answer: The PRA’s overall assessment of whether a home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent is an outcomes-based judgement that the PRA uses for its own purposes of authorisation and supervision [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]. It is not the same as, and should be kept separate from, any advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury, because HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]. In carrying out the assessment, the PRA considers whether the home state supervisor’s regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives, and it assesses the relevant factors in their totality [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. A key practical element is that the PRA places considerable weight on the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. The PRA also looks at how individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group are supervised, and it considers the nature and scale of the firm’s activities in the UK when forming its overall view [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a].

question: For a credit union with more than £50 million in total assets and/or undertaking more complex lending or investment activities, what must it do to assess how key strategic initiatives and external risks could affect its business, and how does this expectation align with the requirement to maintain risk management systems proportionate to its needs and the PRA’s escalation where poor risk management or governance is evidenced?
gold_answer: A credit union that exceeds the stated size threshold and/or undertakes more complex lending or invests in more complex products is expected by the PRA to undertake scenario analysis to identify the impact of key strategic initiatives and external risks on its business, including using scenarios such as weaker loan book performance, higher shares growth, increased arrears, welfare benefit changes, or bank interest rate changes, and it is regarded as good practice to consider combined scenarios [#SRC:865973d64c7565e2]. This scenario analysis should be embedded within the credit union’s broader obligation to maintain proportionate risk management systems that are adequate for the needs of its business [#TGT:b3afbbf8d96609e4]. If there is evidence of poor risk management and/or governance, the credit union should expect the PRA to engage with it on mitigation plans; if it fails to engage or make meaningful progress, it should expect fuller PRA engagement on viability and, where viability is not demonstrated, on orderly closure planning (including insolvent wind-up, solvent wind-down, or transfer of engagements) [#TGT:b3afbbf8d96609e4].

question: If a credit union is large or does more complex lending or investing, what should it do to test how big plans and outside risks could affect it, and how does that fit with having risk management systems that match its business and the PRA’s follow-up if risk management or governance looks poor?
gold_answer: Where a credit union has more than £50 million in total assets and/or carries out more complex lending (for example mortgages or lending to corporates) and/or invests in more complex investment products, the PRA expects it to undertake scenario analysis to identify how key strategic initiatives and external risks could affect its business [#SRC:865973d64c7565e2]. The passage also indicates the types of scenarios that may be used (such as poorer loan book performance, higher than expected shares growth, higher arrears, changes to welfare benefits, or changes in bank interest rates) and notes it is good practice to look at combined scenarios [#SRC:865973d64c7565e2]. This work should sit within the credit union’s wider expectation to have proportionate risk management systems that are adequate for the needs of its business [#TGT:b3afbbf8d96609e4]. If there is evidence of poor risk management and/or governance, the credit union should expect the PRA to engage on mitigation plans; if it does not engage or make meaningful progress, it should expect the PRA to engage more fully on whether it has a viable future and, if not, what orderly closure plans it has (including wind-up, wind-down, or transfer of engagements) [#TGT:b3afbbf8d96609e4].

question: Where a person is a Conduct Rules non-executive director and must comply at all times with the applicable conduct standards, what ongoing disclosure obligation applies in relation to information the FCA or the PRA would reasonably expect to be notified of, and how must that disclosure be handled?
gold_answer: A Conduct Rules non-executive director is under a continuous obligation to comply with the applicable conduct standards at all times, meaning the duty is ongoing rather than event-limited and applies throughout the period they hold that status [#SRC:4b7d02b366371a2f]. Within that always-on compliance framework, one required standard is that the individual must make appropriate disclosure of any information that the FCA or the PRA would reasonably expect to have notice of [#TGT:1ac71628712a0761]. Practically, this requires the non-executive director to identify information that a reasonable regulator would expect to be brought to its attention and to ensure it is disclosed in an appropriate manner, rather than withheld or delayed. The obligation is framed as a “must” requirement and therefore is not discretionary: if the information meets the reasonable-expectation threshold, the director must disclose it appropriately. Because the duty to comply applies “at all times,” the disclosure requirement should be treated as continuing, so the director should be prepared to disclose whenever such information arises during their tenure, not only at periodic reporting points.

question: If you are a Conduct Rules non-executive director, you have to follow the conduct standards all the time. What does that mean for telling the FCA or the PRA about information they would reasonably expect to know?
gold_answer: If you are a Conduct Rules non-executive director, the requirement is to comply with the relevant conduct standards at all times, so the obligation is continuous and applies throughout your role rather than only at specific moments [#SRC:4b7d02b366371a2f]. In effect, you must consider whether information is of a kind that a reasonable regulator would expect to be told, and if so you must ensure it is disclosed in an appropriate way. The wording makes this a mandatory duty (“must”), not an optional step, and it is tied to what the FCA or the PRA would reasonably expect to be notified about. Because your compliance duty applies “at all times,” you should treat the disclosure obligation as ongoing: whenever such information comes up while you are acting as a non-executive director, you are required to make the appropriate disclosure rather than waiting for a later point.

question: For a firm whose general insurance business includes both health insurance based on actuarial principles and other general insurance business, what procedural approach must be used to ensure the calculations are performed separately for each part, and how does the health-insurance-specific percentage substitution apply when the relevant conditions are satisfied?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the health insurance based on actuarial principles and the other general insurance business as two distinct parts for the purposes of applying the relevant calculation steps, so that the process operates separately for each part and yields two separate outcomes: a sum for the health insurance part under the health-insurance calculation and a separate sum for the other business under the other-business calculation [#SRC:da680341ca9e8782]. Within that split approach, when the part being assessed is general insurance business consisting of health insurance based on actuarial principles, the firm must apply the rule that modifies how the relevant percentage is used: the procedure that would otherwise apply is applied with a substituted percentage of 8.66% in place of 26%, but only where the specified conditions are satisfied [#TGT:19c9e8d0b9a70534]. Practically, this means the firm should first identify and segregate the health insurance based on actuarial principles from the other business, then run the applicable calculation separately for each part, applying the percentage substitution only to the health insurance part and only if the stated conditions are met, while leaving the other business to be calculated under its own applicable step and resulting sum.

question: If a firm has some health insurance based on actuarial principles and some other general insurance business, what steps must it follow to keep the calculations separate, and when can it use the lower percentage for the health insurance part?
gold_answer: The firm must split its general insurance business into two parts—(1) health insurance based on actuarial principles and (2) the other business—and then apply the relevant calculation process separately to each part so that the process produces a sum for the health insurance part and a different sum for the other business part [#SRC:da680341ca9e8782]. For the health insurance part specifically, where the general insurance business consists of health insurance based on actuarial principles, the firm applies the relevant calculation with a modified percentage: it substitutes 8.66% for 26%, but only if the stated conditions are satisfied [#TGT:19c9e8d0b9a70534]. In practice, the sequencing is: identify which business falls into the health insurance based on actuarial principles category, keep that category separate from the other business, run the calculation for the health insurance category using the substituted percentage only when the conditions are met, and run the calculation for the other business separately to arrive at its own sum. This ensures the results are not blended across the two parts and that the health-insurance-specific adjustment is applied only in the correct circumstances.

question: When a sub-module within a module is itself composed of other sub-modules, how must the firm determine the capital requirement for that particular sub-module, and how does this interact with the requirement to generate the capital requirement using the standard formula with the specified inputs?
gold_answer: Where a sub-module within a module consists of other sub-modules, the calculation approach must follow the procedural distinction that applies to S i and S j: a sub-module that is not made up of other sub-modules is generated by the standard formula, whereas a sub-module that does consist of other sub-modules is calculated in accordance with the referenced calculation provision [#SRC:783eb897186947a6]. For all such sub-modules of the standard formula that fall within the scope of that cross-reference, the capital requirement for the particular sub-module must be generated by the formula set out in the specified standard-formula provision, applying the stated specifications [#TGT:d0f5710ab3cb3488]. Read together, this means the firm must (i) identify whether the sub-module is composite (i.e., consists of other sub-modules) under the source procedure, and then (ii) ensure that the resulting capital requirement is produced using the required standard-formula generation method and specifications for the relevant sub-modules, rather than treating the composite sub-module as if it were a standalone sub-module generated directly without the cross-referenced calculation step.

question: If a sub-module is made up of other sub-modules, what method must be used to calculate its capital requirement, and how must that result be generated under the standard formula requirements?
gold_answer: You must first apply the source procedure that distinguishes how sub-modules are handled within a module: S i and S j are the capital requirements for sub-modules i and j, and the method depends on whether the sub-module is standalone or built from other sub-modules. If it does not consist of other sub-modules, it is generated by the standard formula; if it does consist of other sub-modules, it must be calculated in accordance with the cross-referenced calculation provision [#SRC:783eb897186947a6]. For all sub-modules of the standard formula that are within the scope of that cross-reference, the capital requirement for the particular sub-module must then be generated by the formula set out in the specified standard-formula provision, applying the required specifications [#TGT:d0f5710ab3cb3488]. In practice, this means you cannot treat a composite sub-module the same way as a simple one: you must recognize it as composite under the source rule and ensure the capital requirement is produced using the required formula and specifications for those sub-modules.

question: When applying the PRA’s procedure for informing a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement, how must the methodology be scoped between the chapter focused on credit risk and the broader set of risk categories covered by the PRA’s Pillar 2A methodologies, and what does that imply for sequencing the assessment across risks?
gold_answer: The PRA’s procedure for informing a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement should be scoped by reading the credit-risk methodology in the chapter as one component within the PRA’s wider Pillar 2A methodologies framework. The chapter establishes the methodology the PRA uses specifically to inform the setting of a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement for credit risk [#TGT:71828950bd20348f]. The broader Pillar 2A methodologies set out the methodologies the PRA will use to inform the setting of a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement across multiple risk categories, including credit risk as well as market risk, operational risk, counterparty credit risk, credit concentration risk, interest rate risk in the banking book (IRRBB), pension obligation risk, and group risk (including RFB group risk) [#SRC:d236289c09b769e3]. Taken together, this implies that the PRA’s overall Pillar 2A-setting process should treat credit risk as a defined methodological stream that sits alongside other risk streams, with the credit-risk chapter guiding the credit-risk component while the broader methodologies define the full set of risks that may need to be assessed to inform the firm’s overall Pillar 2A capital requirement.

question: If you are following the PRA’s method to set a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement, how do you use the credit risk chapter together with the wider PRA Pillar 2A methodologies that also cover other risks?
gold_answer: You should use the credit risk chapter as the PRA’s specific methodology for informing the credit risk part of a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement, while also recognising that it sits within a broader PRA approach that covers additional risk types. The chapter is limited in scope to the methodology the PRA uses to inform the setting of a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement for credit risk [#TGT:71828950bd20348f]. Separately, the PRA’s Pillar 2A methodologies describe the methodologies the PRA will use to inform the setting of a firm’s Pillar 2A capital requirement across a wider range of risks, including credit risk, market risk, operational risk, counterparty credit risk, credit concentration risk, interest rate risk in the banking book (IRRBB), pension obligation risk, and group risk (including RFB group risk) [#SRC:d236289c09b769e3]. Using both together means you do not treat the credit risk chapter as the entire Pillar 2A process; instead, you apply it for credit risk and look to the broader methodologies to understand which other risk categories may also need to be addressed when informing the firm’s overall Pillar 2A capital requirement.

question: Where a participant firm stops conducting business that could generate a protected claim by an eligible claimant and notifies the FSCS during a financial year, how does the scope of continued treatment as a participant firm interact with the situation where a firm ceases to be a participant firm or begins carrying out activities within one or more insurance classes part way through that same financial year?
gold_answer: Taken together, the provisions address how a firm is treated for the remainder of a compensation scheme financial year when its status or activities change mid-year. Under the SOURCE, if a participant firm ceases to conduct business that could give rise to a protected claim by an eligible claimant and it notifies the FSCS accordingly, the firm does not immediately fall outside the relevant scope; instead, it continues to be treated as a participant firm for the rest of the financial year in which the notice is given, specifically as a participant firm to which the referenced application applies until year-end [#SRC:9b1e1dd387715b19]. The TARGET frames the same timing issue more broadly by capturing circumstances where a firm either ceases to be a participant firm or carries out activities within one or more insurance classes part way through a financial year of the compensation scheme [#TGT:9efdd1275a936ea0]. Read together, the scope boundary is that mid-year cessation or mid-year commencement of insurance-class activities does not necessarily end the firm’s treatment within the scheme immediately; rather, the year-end point is the relevant cut-off where the SOURCE’s notification condition is met and the TARGET’s mid-year change scenario is in view.

question: If a participant firm stops doing business that could lead to a protected claim and tells the FSCS during the year, is it still treated as a participant firm until the year ends, even if it stops being a participant firm or starts doing activities in one or more insurance classes part way through that year?
gold_answer: Yes, the combined scope indicates that a mid-year change does not automatically mean the firm is treated as outside the scheme for the rest of that year. The SOURCE sets a specific condition: when a participant firm ceases to conduct business that could give rise to a protected claim by an eligible claimant and it notifies the FSCS, the firm is treated as a participant firm for the remainder of the financial year of the compensation scheme in which the notice is given, and it is treated as one to which the referenced application applies until the end of that year [#SRC:9b1e1dd387715b19]. The TARGET highlights the broader mid-year scenarios that can trigger questions about scope—where a firm ceases to be a participant firm or carries out activities within one or more insurance classes part way through a financial year of the compensation scheme [#TGT:9efdd1275a936ea0]. Putting them together, if the SOURCE’s notification situation applies, the firm remains treated as a participant firm through year-end even though the TARGET contemplates that its participant status or insurance-class activities may change during the year.

question: Where a firm is permitted to adjust the relevant percentage factor for a currency pegged to the euro, how must it treat the financial resources of the parties that guarantee the pegging when assessing whether the conditions for that adjustment are satisfied?
gold_answer: When a firm is considering whether it can use the permission to adjust the relevant percentage factor for currencies pegged to the euro, it must ensure that its assessment of eligibility incorporates the financial strength of the parties that support the peg. Specifically, the firm’s ability to rely on the adjustment is conditional on meeting stated requirements for euro-pegged currencies, and the firm is permitted to make the adjustment only if those requirements are met [#TGT:6d25f010b1a021ba]. In parallel, for the purposes of the relevant assessment framework, the firm has an explicit obligation to take into account the financial resources of the parties that guarantee the pegging [#SRC:065e7bb215b17ee1]. Read together, this means the firm should not treat the peg as a purely mechanical feature of the currency; it must evaluate the guarantor parties’ financial resources as part of the overall determination of whether the prerequisites for applying the adjusted factor are satisfied. The firm should therefore document how those parties’ financial resources were considered in reaching the conclusion that the adjustment conditions are met, before applying any adjusted factor.

question: If a firm wants to use the option to change the percentage factor for a currency pegged to the euro, does it have to look at the financial resources of the parties that keep the peg in place, and why?
gold_answer: Yes. The firm may change the relevant percentage factor for currencies pegged to the euro only if it meets the stated requirements attached to that permission [#TGT:6d25f010b1a021ba]. Separately, when applying the relevant framework for pegged currencies, the firm must take into account the financial resources of the parties that guarantee the pegging [#SRC:065e7bb215b17ee1]. Putting these together, the firm cannot decide it qualifies for the adjustment without considering whether the parties supporting the peg have sufficient financial resources, because that consideration is a required input to the pegging analysis. In practice, the firm should treat the guarantor parties’ financial resources as part of the evidence base for concluding that the conditions for using the adjustment are met. This helps ensure the firm’s decision to apply an adjusted factor is grounded in the robustness of the peg’s support, rather than assuming the peg is reliable without assessing the guarantors’ capacity.

question: Where a firm enters into a business relationship or contract with an organisation to provide a product or service, how should the firm determine whether that organisation is a third party and whether the arrangement is within the PRA Rulebook definition of outsourcing (including where performance is via sub-outsourcing and would otherwise be undertaken by the firm)?
gold_answer: Under the SOURCE definition, the organisation is treated as a third party where it has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]. The TARGET then sets the test for whether the arrangement with that third party is “outsourcing”: it must be an arrangement of any form between the firm and a service provider (whether supervised or not) under which the service provider performs a process, service, or activity that the firm would otherwise undertake itself, including where delivery is indirect through sub-outsourcing [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. In applying that definition to an arrangement with a third party, firms should also assess whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis, as this is a key consideration in determining whether the arrangement falls within the outsourcing definition [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. If the arrangement with the third party does not meet the outsourcing definition, the SOURCE clarifies that existing outsourcing requirements only apply to arrangements that do meet that definition, and do not apply to other firm–third party arrangements outside it [#SRC:ae60277c11940928].

question: How do the SOURCE definition of a third party and the TARGET definition of outsourcing interact to delineate which firm arrangements are captured as outsourcing versus other third-party arrangements, particularly where the service provider performs activities the firm would otherwise perform and does so on a recurrent or ongoing basis?
gold_answer: The SOURCE establishes who is in scope as a third party: an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]. The TARGET then determines when an arrangement with such a third party is classified as outsourcing: it is any arrangement between a firm and a service provider (whether a supervised entity or not) where the provider performs a process, service, or activity—directly or via sub-outsourcing—that would otherwise be undertaken by the firm itself [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. In addition, when assessing whether a third-party arrangement falls within that outsourcing definition, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. This interaction is important because the SOURCE clarifies that existing outsourcing requirements only apply to “outsourcing” as defined, and they do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside the outsourcing definition [#SRC:ae60277c11940928].

question: If a firm signs a contract with an organisation to provide a product or service, when is that organisation treated as a third party, and when does the arrangement count as outsourcing under the PRA Rulebook (including if the work is done through sub-outsourcing and would otherwise be done by the firm)?
gold_answer: The organisation is a third party where it has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]. Whether the arrangement with that third party is “outsourcing” depends on the PRA Rulebook definition: it must be an arrangement of any form between the firm and a service provider (whether a supervised entity or not) where the provider performs a process, service, or activity that the firm would otherwise undertake itself, and this can be done directly or through sub-outsourcing [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. When deciding if a third-party arrangement fits that outsourcing definition, firms should also consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. This matters because the SOURCE explains that existing outsourcing requirements only apply to arrangements that meet the outsourcing definition, and they do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside it [#SRC:ae60277c11940928].

question: How can a firm tell the difference between (1) a normal arrangement with a third party and (2) outsourcing, using the third-party definition and the outsourcing definition (including the idea of ongoing or recurrent performance)?
gold_answer: First, identify whether the counterparty is a third party: under the SOURCE, it is an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]. Next, decide whether the arrangement with that third party is outsourcing under the TARGET: outsourcing is any arrangement between a firm and a service provider (whether supervised or not) where the provider performs a process, service, or activity—either directly or via sub-outsourcing—that the firm would otherwise carry out itself [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. The TARGET also says that, when assessing whether a third-party arrangement falls within the outsourcing definition, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. Finally, the SOURCE clarifies the consequence of this classification: existing outsourcing requirements only apply to arrangements that meet the outsourcing definition, and they do not apply to other firm–third party arrangements outside it [#SRC:ae60277c11940928].

question: Where a credit union provides transactional account services and also is carrying out any additional activity or has more than 15,000 members, what must it do on an ongoing basis while those transactional account services are being provided, and how does that continuing duty relate to the further requirements triggered by the additional-activity or membership threshold condition?
gold_answer: If a credit union provides transactional account services, it has a continuing obligation that applies for the entire period it is providing those services: it must at all times comply with the referenced compliance requirement tied to that service activity [#SRC:c3be98a9a9c0f744]. Separately, when the same credit union is carrying out any additional activity or has more than 15,000 members, it is also subject to an additional set of mandatory requirements that are triggered by that condition and expressed as “must” obligations [#TGT:ea60bc9486906c80]. Read together, the credit union must treat the “at all times” duty as an always-on baseline for its transactional account services, and it must also identify whether it meets either of the trigger conditions (additional activity or the membership threshold) and then comply with the further mandatory steps that follow from that trigger. In practice, this means the credit union cannot pause or defer the ongoing compliance duty while it addresses the separate obligations that arise from its additional activities or larger membership size; both sets of requirements apply concurrently when their respective conditions are met.

question: If a credit union offers transactional account services, and it also either carries out any additional activity or has more than 15,000 members, what does it have to do the whole time it is offering those services, and what extra “must” requirements are triggered by the additional activity or member count?
gold_answer: A credit union that provides transactional account services has an ongoing duty that applies continuously during the period it is providing those services: it must at all times comply with the specified compliance requirement linked to providing transactional account services [#SRC:c3be98a9a9c0f744]. In addition, if that credit union is carrying out any additional activity or has more than 15,000 members, it falls into a category that triggers further mandatory obligations—introduced as requirements the credit union “must” meet—because of the additional activity or the size of its membership [#TGT:ea60bc9486906c80]. Put simply, the “all the time” requirement applies whenever the credit union is offering transactional account services, and the separate trigger (additional activity or more than 15,000 members) adds another layer of required actions. The credit union should therefore check whether it meets either trigger condition and ensure it satisfies those extra requirements while still maintaining continuous compliance for its transactional account services.

question: For capital adequacy calculations for financial conglomerates that apply after 01/01/2027, how should an institution align the future version of Annex 2 with the accounting consolidation approach referenced in the Financial Groups Directive, and what concrete method label should be used to evidence that alignment?
gold_answer: Where an institution is preparing capital adequacy calculations for financial conglomerates for the period after 01/01/2027, it should treat the applicable framework as the future version of Annex 2 and ensure that its calculation approach is aligned to the accounting consolidation approach identified in the Financial Groups Directive materials. Practically, that means the institution should map its post‑01/01/2027 capital adequacy calculation work under the future Annex 2 context to the method explicitly described as the Accounting Consolidation Method, and it should document that the method used corresponds to the table entry that identifies “PART 1” as the relevant method description. This provides a clear, auditable linkage between the timing and scope of the capital adequacy calculations for financial conglomerates (after 01/01/2027) and the specific consolidation method label used for the calculation basis, avoiding ambiguity about which consolidation approach is being applied. This alignment is supported by the future Annex 2 framing in the SOURCE [#SRC:e8a9cb26c138e38f] and the method identification in the TARGET table describing the Accounting Consolidation Method under the Financial Groups Directive [#TGT:78cd1c923c80862d].

question: If you are doing capital adequacy calculations for a financial conglomerate for dates after 01/01/2027, which consolidation method should you tie them to, based on the Financial Groups Directive table, and how does that connect to the future Annex 2 version?
gold_answer: For capital adequacy calculations for a financial conglomerate that are intended to apply after 01/01/2027, you should treat the work as falling under the future version of Annex 2 and then anchor the calculation basis to the consolidation method identified in the Financial Groups Directive table. The table points you to the Accounting Consolidation Method, described as the method in “PART 1,” so your documentation and working papers should show that your post‑01/01/2027 Annex 2 calculations are being performed using that accounting consolidation approach. In other words, the SOURCE establishes the timing and scope—capital adequacy calculations for financial conglomerates after 01/01/2027—while the TARGET provides the concrete method label you should reference when describing how the calculations are consolidated. Keeping both references together helps ensure that reviewers can see (i) why the future Annex 2 version is relevant for the period in question and (ii) which consolidation method you used to implement it. This linkage is grounded in the SOURCE [#SRC:e8a9cb26c138e38f] and the TARGET method table [#TGT:78cd1c923c80862d].

question: When calculating the basic SCR, how must a firm treat an exposure that is fully, unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by a body listed in 3D1, and what constraints apply to whether that guarantee may be recognised in the basic SCR calculation?
gold_answer: A firm must apply two linked obligations. First, for the specified purposes, where an exposure is fully, unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by a body listed in 3D1 and the guarantee meets the requirements set out in 3G9, the firm must treat that exposure as an exposure to the central government [#SRC:701ce6aa38be752a]. Second, when calculating the basic SCR, the firm must not automatically recognise every guarantee it identifies; it must only recognise guarantees where recognition is explicitly referred to in the relevant Chapter and only where, in addition to meeting the qualitative criteria in 3G2 and 3G3, the applicable criteria are met [#TGT:9d80cba8634278ab]. Read together, this means the “central government” treatment for the exposure depends on the guarantee meeting the stated conditions, but the use of that guarantee within the basic SCR calculation is further constrained by the Chapter’s explicit recognition framework and the required qualitative criteria, plus any additional criteria that must be satisfied.

question: If a firm has an exposure that is fully, unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by a body listed in 3D1, what must the firm do with that exposure, and when is the firm allowed to count that guarantee in the basic SCR calculation?
gold_answer: The firm has to follow both rules at the same time. On the exposure treatment side, if the exposure is fully, unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by a body listed in 3D1 and the guarantee meets the requirements in 3G9, the firm must treat the exposure as an exposure to the central government [#SRC:701ce6aa38be752a]. On the basic SCR side, the firm cannot assume that any guarantee it has identified can be used in the calculation: it must only recognise guarantees in the basic SCR where the Chapter explicitly refers to recognising them, and only where the qualitative criteria in 3G2 and 3G3 are met, along with the other criteria that must be satisfied [#TGT:9d80cba8634278ab]. So, even if the guarantee is strong enough to drive “central government” treatment under the first obligation, the firm still must check that the basic SCR rules explicitly allow recognition and that the qualitative and other required criteria are met before using it in the calculation.

question: For purposes of interpreting EU Guidelines and Recommendations, how should a firm understand the Bank of England and PRA approach set out in their SoP after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, and what is the publication date associated with the referenced Bank of England paper that supports that SoP?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the relevant interpretive position as the one articulated jointly by the Bank of England and PRA in their statement of policy (SoP) on the “Interpretation of EU Guidelines and Recommendations,” which is expressly framed as the Bank of England and PRA approach after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU [#SRC:0d11214b8a087d7c]. To evidence and anchor that approach, the cross-referenced Bank of England paper identified in the paired material is dated April 2019, and it is the item linked under the same “Interpretation of EU Guidelines and Recommendations—BoE and PRA approach SoP” description [#TGT:42ffe564af71a480]. Read together, the SOURCE establishes the subject matter and regulatory actors (the Bank of England and PRA) and clarifies that the SoP is specifically about how EU Guidelines and Recommendations are to be interpreted in the post-withdrawal context, while the TARGET provides the concrete publication timing (April 2019) and the corresponding Bank of England web reference for the paper. Accordingly, compliance documentation should cite the Bank of England and PRA SoP as the governing interpretive statement and record April 2019 as the associated publication date for the referenced supporting paper.

question: When you need to understand how EU Guidelines and Recommendations should be interpreted after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, which Bank of England and PRA document should you look to, and what date is given for the linked Bank of England paper about that approach?
gold_answer: You should look to the Bank of England and PRA SoP that is specifically titled around the “Interpretation of EU Guidelines and Recommendations” and describes the Bank of England and PRA approach after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU [#SRC:0d11214b8a087d7c]. The paired reference then points you to the related Bank of England paper for that same topic and provides the publication date as April 2019, alongside the Bank of England URL where the paper is hosted [#TGT:42ffe564af71a480]. Using both pieces together matters: the SOURCE tells you the correct actors (the Bank of England and PRA) and the purpose of the document (how to interpret EU Guidelines and Recommendations in the post-withdrawal setting), while the TARGET supplies the concrete timing detail (April 2019) and the specific web reference for the paper. In practice, this means your internal compliance note should identify the Bank of England and PRA SoP as the interpretive basis and record April 2019 as the date associated with the linked Bank of England paper supporting that approach.

question: Where a firm has already had an investigation into its financial condition for its long-term insurance business carried out other than under the relevant procedure, how must the firm still comply with the requirement to ensure an annual investigation is made, including who must perform it and the basis on which it must be conducted?
gold_answer: The firm’s core obligation is to ensure that an investigation is made annually into its financial condition in respect of its long-term insurance business. That annual investigation must be carried out using methods and assumptions determined by the firm, and it must be performed by the person or persons who for the time being are appointed to perform the actuarial function [#TGT:7fd5f2cd8f30684f]. The procedural context recognises that an investigation into the firm’s financial condition in respect of its long-term insurance business may have been made “other than” under the referenced procedure, and that situation triggers further procedural handling (“either …”) rather than removing the annual requirement [#SRC:9ee08e95e6588105]. Accordingly, even if the firm has already undertaken an investigation outside that procedure, it must still ensure the annual investigation requirement is met in the manner specified: the firm determines the methods and assumptions, and the appointed actuarial function holder(s) perform the investigation. The existence of a non-procedure investigation is therefore a sequencing/route issue, not an exemption from the annual investigation obligation.

question: If an investigation into the firm’s financial condition for its long-term insurance business has already been done outside the usual procedure, what does the firm still have to do each year, and who must carry out that work?
gold_answer: Even where an investigation into the financial condition of the firm in respect of its long-term insurance business has been made other than under the referenced procedure (which the procedure text anticipates and then directs into an “either …” pathway) [#SRC:9ee08e95e6588105], the firm still has an ongoing duty to ensure an investigation is made annually into its financial condition for that long-term insurance business [#TGT:7fd5f2cd8f30684f]. The annual investigation is not just a general review: it must be conducted in accordance with the methods and assumptions determined by the firm, and it must be carried out by the person or persons who for the time being are appointed to perform the actuarial function [#TGT:7fd5f2cd8f30684f]. In practical terms, the earlier investigation done outside the procedure does not remove the annual requirement; the firm must still ensure that, each year, the investigation is performed by the appointed actuarial function holder(s) and is based on the firm’s chosen methods and assumptions, while also treating the “other than under” situation as a procedural condition that requires following the specified route in the procedure text [#SRC:9ee08e95e6588105].

question: When a firm plans a solvent exit—i.e., ceasing its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent—how should it address the transfer or repayment of deposits and the end-state change to its permission, and what additional statutory framework is referenced for the control of any business transfer that may be used as part of that approach?
gold_answer: A solvent exit is described as the process through which a firm ceases its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent, and the firm should plan to transfer or repay (or both) all deposits as part of that process [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. The planning expectation is that the firm builds in sufficient time and resources to support meeting liabilities when they fall due and to enable the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits, so that the firm can complete the exit in an orderly way while remaining solvent [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. The solvent exit is then expected to end with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission or with the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission, described as removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. Where the firm’s approach involves a business transfer as a mechanism to move deposits or related business, the cross-reference indicates that further details on the control of business transfer are set out in Part VII of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) [#TGT:eac5c4e524b93e43].

question: If a firm wants to do a solvent exit (stop its PRA-regulated activities but stay solvent), what does it need to plan for around paying back or moving deposits and changing its permission, and where should it look for more detail if it uses a business transfer to do that?
gold_answer: A solvent exit is the process through which a firm ceases its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent, and the firm should plan to transfer or repay (or both) all deposits as part of that exit [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. The firm’s solvent exit planning should also include enough time and resources to support the firm in meeting liabilities when they fall due and in carrying out the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits, so the firm can complete the process without becoming insolvent [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. The end of the solvent exit is tied to a permission outcome: it will end with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission, or with cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (referred to as removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission) [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. If the firm’s plan relies on a business transfer as the way to move business connected to deposits, the referenced place to find further details on the control of business transfer is Part VII of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) [#TGT:eac5c4e524b93e43].

question: For a firm, how should the Chief Executive function (SMF1) be classified when it is one of the functions listed in the specified range, and what responsibility test determines whether the role is in fact the Chief Executive function (SMF1) under the governing body’s immediate authority?
gold_answer: Where the Chief Executive function (SMF1) falls within the set of functions identified in the specified range, it must be treated as a controlled function and also as a PRA senior management function, because each function in that range is expressly classified in that way [#SRC:db44207a07b3ce1d]. Whether a particular individual is performing “The Chief Executive function (SMF1)” depends on the responsibility test in the definition: the person must have responsibility, under the immediate authority of the governing body, either alone or jointly with others, for carrying out the management of the conduct of the whole of the business (or relevant activities) of a firm [#TGT:455a69762013a60b]. In practice, this means the classification consequence (controlled function and PRA senior management function) attaches once the role is within the specified range, while the definitional trigger for SMF1 focuses on the nature and scope of responsibility (management of the conduct of the whole business or relevant activities) and the governance relationship (immediate authority of the governing body), including where responsibility is shared jointly with others. This aligns the label “The Chief Executive function (SMF1)” with both its responsibility criteria and its regulatory categorisation.

question: If someone is performing the Chief Executive function (SMF1), what does that role mean in terms of responsibility under the governing body, and how is it treated when it is one of the functions in the specified range?
gold_answer: “The Chief Executive function (SMF1)” means having responsibility, under the immediate authority of the governing body, either alone or jointly with others, for carrying out the management of the conduct of the whole of the business (or relevant activities) of a firm [#TGT:455a69762013a60b]. Separately, the regulatory treatment depends on whether the function is within the specified range: each of the functions in that range is a controlled function and a PRA senior management function [#SRC:db44207a07b3ce1d]. Put together, you identify SMF1 by checking the responsibility test (scope: whole business or relevant activities; reporting line: immediate authority of the governing body; and whether the responsibility is held alone or jointly). If the Chief Executive function (SMF1) is one of the functions in the specified range, then it is not just a title—it carries the formal status of being both a controlled function and a PRA senior management function. This combined reading ensures you apply the definition of SMF1 to the person’s actual responsibilities and then apply the classification that attaches to functions in the specified range.
